Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Spatial Dynamics of Burn Severity and Post-fire Recovery in the High Park Fire Burn Area
Award.AbstractNarration:
The western United States has experienced an unprecedented period of wildfires in the last two decades, and both land owners and downstream water users are vulnerable to wildfire and its effects on erosion and water quality. The 2012 High Park Fire was the second largest fire in Colorado history (over 35,000 ha burned) and burned in a wildland-urban interface of public and private lands located north and west of Fort Collins, CO. This research will provide a unique understanding of the second largest fire in Colorado history. The award will enable studies of the biological and physical dynamics of burn severity and post-fire recovery 2012 High Park Fire using an integrative approach that combines high resolution remote sensing provided by the National Ecological Observatory Airborne Observatory (AOP) remote sensing instruments and in situ field collected data. The award will provide funds for developing an integrated understanding of the biological and physical responses to fire across a spatially complex landscape. The study has six objectives: (1) characterize the post-fire landscape, (2) investigate the effects of pre-fire landscape conditions on burn severity, (3) examine the post-fire biological response, (4) examine the post-fire physical response, (5) conduct an integrated biological and physical assessment of the fire impacts on the Cache la Poudre watershed, and (6) inform future AOP applications. Two of these (1 & 6) are methodological objectives aimed at developing strategies for using AOP data to examine landscape response to a large disturbance, and the remaining (2-5) are scientific objectives related to understanding controls on burn severity and post-fire response.

The data on the spectral, topographic and forest structure qualities of the recovering landscape will facilitate an understanding of the physical and biological processes of recovery within a common spatially-explicit three-dimensional framework. By integrating the extensive information in the airborne remote sensing data with field monitoring, the research allows examination of spatial and temporal dynamics at a level of detail that would not be feasible with field measurements alone. The combined biological and physical analyses will facilitate understanding of the feedbacks between vegetation changes and post-fire erosion and deposition patterns. Combining the field and remote sensing datasets will allow an assessment of the impact of the fire, provide data products useful to the scientific and management communities, and support future research on ecosystem recovery. A postdoc and two graduate students will be fully integrated in the research, thus building awareness and capacity for using airborne remote sensing data in the future.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2012 High Park fire burnt an extensive region of approximately 87,000 acres west of Fort Collins, CO and impacted a significant area that includes the watersheds used for collection of household water for several Colorado cities (Fort Collins and Greeley). The region had suffered significant infestation of pine beetle prior to the fire that resulted in large scale lodgepole pine mortality. Primary scientific goals included investigation into the impact of the pine beetle infestation and tree mortality on fire behavior due to fuel loading, resulting burn severity, soil erosion and deposition and the correlation to pre-fire vegeation and burn severity, and finally to post-fire trajectories regarding the regrowth of native and invasive vegetation.

The objective of the NSF award to the National Ecological Observatory Network was to obtain a multi-year series of high quality airborne remote sensing data over the High Park burn scar and surrounding unaffected areas. The award for the airborne acquistion of the High Park burn scar also served as an early prototype activity for developing NEON's rapid response capability to respond to natural or human caused disasters. These type of activities are expected to span fires such as the High Park fire to other man-made disasters such as oil spills. These type of flights are expected to be a challenge and stretch the capabilities of the Airborne Remote Sensing team due to the required rapid response and the need to base flight operations out of previosuly unvisted locations.

The award to NEON to collect the multi-year airborne remote sensing data was partnered with an award to Colorado State University (Dr. Michael Lefsky) to collect in-situ data focused on the vegetation and hydrological impacts of the High Park fire. The airborne remote sensing data is key to obtaining maximum scientific benefit from the extensive field work conducted by Lefsky et al and extending the detailed in-situ results to the regional scale impacted by the High Park fire. 

NEON AOP collected data over the High Park burn scar initially in 2012 under a seperate NSF RAPID grants (1250576 and 1264433). This data was collected during the first year of operating the first generation AOP prototypical payload. This data was mixed in quality due to several issues with the airborne sensors. Subsequently, the High Park burn scar has been collected annually in 2013, 2014, and in 2015 with improved airborne sensors and improved flight planning based on the lessons learned in 2012. The 2012 and 2014 airborne acquistions were scheduled after the Colorado monsoon season in October while the 2013 and 2015 collects were conducted in June/July prior to the monsoon season.

The NEON AOP payload conists of a high-fidelity Visible to Shortwave (VSWIR) imaging spectrometer (NIS), a small footprint discrete and full waveform lidar, and high-resolution digital camera, and high-accuracy GPS/IMU to enable rigirous orthorectification of the collected data. The sensors are tied together in a common frame to minimize co-registration errors. Typical NEON flight acquisitions are conducted at 1000-m Above Ground Level (AGL) during clear sky conditions to enable accurate atmospheric correction of the imaging spectrometer data. The nominal flight altitude results in full spectroscopic data from 380-nm to 2500-nm at one meter ground sampling distance. The discrete and waveform lidar parameters are set to encompass the full field-of-view of the NIS and maintain 2-4 lidar points per square meter. The Digital camera natively collects Red-Green-Blue (RGB) data at 10-cm scales. Both the digital camera data and the NIS data are orthorectified utilizing a Digital Surface Model (DSM) created from the discrete lidar point cloud data.

While still under development, the AOP algorithms and processing infrastructure have improved significantly due to the early lessons learned during the High Park collects and are currently able to routinely process incoming data from the airborne remote sensing platforms. The airborne data collected annually over the High Park burn scar was processed by NEON to Level-1 and higher data products. These Level-1 data products include ortho-rectified atmospherically-corrected spectral reflectance (spectrometer), Lidar discrete return point clouds (Lidar), waveform LiDAR waveforms, and orthorectified digital images (airborne camera). Some higher-level products such as a Digital Terrain Model and Digital Surface Model from the Lidar point cloud data were also produced. This data was made available and distributed to the High Park stakeholders and is slated to be released to the general public thorugh NEON's typical distribution channels.
